speaker: BEGGARS
line: Paise! Paise!

speaker: CUSTOMS AGENT
line: Home to America, Mr. Potocki?

speaker: MR. POTOCKI
line: Not a moment too soon.

speaker: CUSTOMS AGENT
line: Next in line. Passport, please.

speaker: MR. POTOCKI
line: Poor bastard.

speaker: MR. POTOCKI
line: Here's 50 paise. Buy yourself some WD-40.

speaker: CIUT TO
line: nan

speaker: MR. POTOCKI
line: Oh, for crying out loud. Listen, fella, I already gave.

speaker: MR. POTOCKI
line: Do you understand English?

speaker: BELLBOY
line: Long flight, huh? Bombay to D.C.?

speaker: BELLBOY
line: You know, I always wondered do they serve, like, Indian food on the plane?

speaker: BELLBOY
line: If there's anything else I can do for you, sir...

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Things that land in your in-box, huh, Agent Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Good morning. I'm sorry I'm late. I didn't get a chance to look at the case file. The traffic's terrible.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Beltway's a nightmare. Takes longer to get crosstown than it does a plane ride from India, which is where our victim flew in from last night-- Bombay.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who are we talking about?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Hugh Potocki. Importer/exporter from Minneapolis. Laid over in DC on his way home when all this blood drains from his body.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did the M.E. See it? The body?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Yeah. Tox test ruled out hemorrhagic fever, Ebola, anything exotic. Something killed this man but it doesn't seem to be any foreign disease.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No sign of forced entry?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: No. No one was seen coming or going from this room. The maid found the body 20 minutes after a bellman left Mr. Potocki here. Whatever happened, happened fast.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So, basically what you're saying is that nobody knows anything.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: But then I guess that's why it's in your in-box.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: So, what do you think, Agent Scully? Haunted hotel room? Alien invaders? Sloppy vampires?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: There is one small thing. The cops missed it their first time around.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A child's print.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Yeah. That's what it looks like.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: You know there was a ring of thieves when I was back in New York. They used kids for B&E jobs.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mm...

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Squeezing in through cracked windows, that kind of thing. But this, this is beyond.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. From what I see, Agent Doggett, from the way this man died... I doubt it was a kid who did this.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Thanks. I'm not quite ready yet to lose all my faith in humanity.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But regardless, I'd say it's wise you keep an open mind.

speaker: MRS. HOLT
line: The better the economy gets the harder it is to fill these kinds of jobs. And the problem is that people look at it as just a paycheck. They don't realize that as maintenance engineer you are playing an important part in these kids' lives. And I can't tell you how wonderful it is to find someone as enthusiastic as you are, Mr. Burrard. And I understand you can start immediately?

speaker: MRS. HOLT
line: That's wonderful.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Big fella, isn't he?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Big is a relative term, Agent Doggett. It took three strong men to wheel him in here. He tipped the scale at 402 pounds.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Uh, Hugh Potocki was a big man, big appetites. Loved big cars, big houses, big business. Divorced twice. He carried two alimonies, one with child support. Never missed a payment. In fact, he seems to have spoiled his wives and kids.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm missing the point.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: It seems he loved big women, too. Considering the evidence and motives we can probably rule out his ex-wives as suspects.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, considering what I found here today I'd say I have to agree.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Tissue damage. Massive trauma to the lower intestine and the rectal wall.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Is that from something going in or coming out?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, unfortunately there's so much damage that it's hard to tell.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I took MRIs, which reveal further shredding throughout the abdomen and, uh, into the stomach area.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: India's a major transit point for the Golden Triangle. This guy flew in and out of India half a dozen times over the past 18 months.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are you suggesting that he's a mule? A courier of heroine or opiates? Drug dealer?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Fills a latex balloon with heroine, swallows it. We've all seen this kind of thing before but what if somebody got to him en route, forcibly extracted the drugs, tearing it from his stomach?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I'd say, uh, that's a good theory, Agent Doggett, not to mention a graphic one, but there would have been traces left of drugs in his system. Nor does it account for the blood loss that this man experienced.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Then we're right back where we started. Nobody knows anything.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Not exactly. I ran a decay analysis to, uh, determine the time of death. Liver temperature, buildup of gases, extent of rigor-- routine stuff. It's not 100% accurate, but it gives us a range.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: What's the range?

speaker: SCULLY
line: 24 to 36 hours.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Well, that's just wrong.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it would mean that, uh, Mr. Potocki here would have died before he left Bombay.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: No. It would mean that a dead man boarded a plane in India, changed planes in Paris, hailed a cab at Dulles, and then checked into a downtown hotel and tipped the bellman. In my experience, dead men don't tip, Agent Scully.

speaker: [CARRIK
line: Well, we didn't see Mr. Potocki tip. Is this a subtle reference to the possibly dead, nontipping Mulder, i.e. Bad Blood?]

speaker: SCULLY
line: I told you to keep an open mind.

speaker: TREVOR
line: Oh... look what he just did to my scooter.

speaker: QUINTON
line: That's mine!

speaker: TREVOR
line: Yeah, right, you going to take it from me?

speaker: QUINTON'S FATHER
line: Hey! Leave him alone. What's going on here, Quinton?

speaker: QUINTON'S FATHER
line: I know you. Your name's Trevor? You're in seventh grade, right? Don't you guys have anything better to do than pick on sixth graders?

speaker: TREVOR
line: Well, he ran into me.

speaker: QUINTON
line: That's a lie!

speaker: QUINTON'S FATHER
line: Enough. You want to be a bully? Find somebody your own age. I'll talk to your father if I have to. Come on, Quinton.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Yes. Thank you. Sorry to wake you. Good-bye.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Bad connection?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Consulate in New Delhi. Three weeks ago an American businessman was found dead inside his hotel room. Take a look.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: A Mr. Albert Brecht of Spokane. The reports have been hard to piece together. The medical records are in Hindi. Death certificate's in Farsi and the news accounts are in... I don't know—letters I've never seen before but I did get you a translation of Mr. Brecht's autopsy results.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Internal trauma. Tearing in the abdomen. You're the doctor-- it sounds like the same MO, doesn't it, Agent Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Look at this. Albert Brecht's passport was a recent issue and it has his weight at 205 pounds whereas here, an Indian medical examiner has him listed at 238 pounds just two hours after his death.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Well, if there's one thing people lie about, it's their weight.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, that's a pretty big lie. I mean, that's a 33 pound discrepancy.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Well, he was a big man, that's for sure.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. As was our DC victim. All the better for accommodation.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Accommodation?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, something has to account for the weight gain, Agent Doggett. What if, whatever it is that killed these men entered and exited them of its own free will? I mean, something.... small... with small hands... living... inside the victims as a... as a stowaway of sorts.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: You know I agree that having an open mind is important to crime solving, but... this theory of yours requires an openness that I'm... … I'm just not comfortable with.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I understand, Agent Doggett and I can't prove it... but I bet that if we had weighed Hugh Potocki when he first arrived here from Bombay that he would have been 33 pounds heavier than his corpse.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: It's a theory, Agent Scully, but to my mind and... pretty much the rest of me, it-it... doesn't work.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I appreciate your resistance but so far this evidence supports it.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Except one thing... Even if there was something living inside of Hugh Potocki when he arrived here from Bombay... you said that Mr. Potocki was already dead.

speaker: QUINTON
line: Dad? Dad. Dad! Dad! Dad!!

speaker: QUINTON'S FATHER
line: Quint, what is it?

speaker: QUINTON
line: There's a man in here.

speaker: QUINTON'S FATHER
line: What? What are you talking about?

speaker: QUINTON
line: He was here, Dad. Right over there. He had no legs!

speaker: QUINTON'S FATHER
line: Quinton... Quinton, listen to me. The things that you imagine, the things that-that you dream... are not real. And what's not real can't hurt you.

speaker: QUINTON
line: But, Dad, it was real. It was.

speaker: QUINTON'S FATHER
line: Quint, there's nobody here.

speaker: QUINTON'S FATHER
line: Try to get some sleep. Okay?

speaker: NEWSGUY 1
line: There's no denying the world order has changed. The United States is the sole Super Power-- in both a military sense and an economic one. With this comes responsibility.

speaker: NEWSGUYS
line: No one's dismissing American responsibilities, here or abroad. But Third World debt relief, in my view would be a positive step toward solving Third World issues and Third World problems. Well, now it's my turn to disagree. Relieving that debt would allow these countries to find solutions without American intervention... I think you're being naive... There's no denying the world order has changed...

speaker: QUINTON
line: Dad?

speaker: QUINTON
line: Dad?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: The first dead body I saw, I was 19 and a marine. This boy... criminy.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. That's not all he claims he saw.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: That's what the cops told me. That's why I thought we should come down here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He said he called his dad in because there was something in his room. I asked him to describe it. He said that it was a munchkin. That it had no legs. And that it was keeping itself up with its arms.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Well, that's a pretty good trick considering what I just found upstairs. Palm prints in the boy's bedroom. They match the one's we found in Potocki's room. And that's the good news. It just doesn't serve your theory because this thing didn't get in here in anybody's body. It came in through the bedroom window.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How can you be sure?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: There was another print on the sill outside the locked window. And somebody must have closed it after this thing got in.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Right. Which is exactly what the boy said that his father did. But it's the father that I have a problem with here. I mean he had none of the massive hemorrhaging that we found in Mr. Potocki. In the coroner's initial report, he makes it sound like the guy died of a cerebral embolism. The one salient detail in the external exam were the eyes... in which only the blood vessels are broken.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Unless that's just the first stage.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is Special Agent Dana Scully. I am a medical doctor about to perform an unauthorized procedure on a body. The, uh … the subject is a Caucasian male. Age, uh... I don't remember at this particular time. His height is about six feet. And his weight is... quite possibly subject to change.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I suppose distention could be due to decomposition gases... but that seems unlikely.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh.

speaker: MRS. HOLT
line: Reliability's one of the most important parts of your job. We were very worried when you didn't show up this morning.

speaker: (CLOSED CAPTIONING
line: CHUCK BURKS: They take religious devotion to an extreme.)

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: They're called Fakir-- ascetic masters bound to acts of self-torture to attain enlightenment.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: We shot this video when I was traveling through India back in the late '70s... Oh, man, look at my hair back then.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Agent Mulder consulted with Dr. Burks on occasion and I have to admit that I've been skeptical of him in the past but he does have certain insights.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Well, we could use some insights.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Uh, well, I-I'm embarrassed to admit but I-I'm not sure I know what the heck's going on here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: These ascetic masters... they have abilities?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Oh, absolutely. An-and abilities similar to those you told me about on the phone have been ascribed to what are know as Siddhi mystics. The Siddhi are a very mysterious and particularly powerful order of Fakirs. These Siddhi, they pass on their secret practices from father to son gaining occult powers with each generation.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: What kind of powers?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Powers of the mind. Powers that help them manipulate reality. Powers that allow them to become invisible or tiny as an atom.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Well, I hope they're tiny. Where, whoever it is, is going.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Chuck... Could one of these Siddhi mystics make you believe that he vanished in a room when in fact, he's standing right in front of you?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Totally. Or disguise themselves appearing in front of you as, uh, well, virtually anyone.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: I'm sorry, Dr. Burks, you're a... you're a professor of what?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: I run the Advanced Digital Imaging lab at the University of Maryland. And, um, I dabble.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: You dabble. Well, this has been... insightful.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Doesn't surprise me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: It's hard to believe in something when you can't understand it.

speaker: QUINTON
line: Get out of here.

speaker: TREVOR
line: No, just... let me talk to you.

speaker: QUINTON
line: Leave me alone.

speaker: TREVOR
line: No, I want to say I'm sorry.

speaker: QUINTON
line: No, you're not.

speaker: TREVOR
line: Look, I am. Would you just... listen.

speaker: TREVOR
line: I'm... sorry about your Dad.

speaker: TREVOR
line: I, I think I know who did it.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Agent Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Chuck. Thank you for, uh, coming down here again.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Not at all. Uh... I'm just a little curious. I mean, it's always Mulder who'd been doing all the calling and...

speaker: SCULLY
line: This, uh... this case, I-I-I-I'm just... I'm trying to see it the way that Mulder would and... please have a seat.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Of course. So, what's seems to be the problem?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You described these, uh, Siddhi mystics as being religious men.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Extremely. They believe their powers derive directly from the divine.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So, presumably using those powers for murder would be in opposition of that?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Worse. It would violate the very foundation of ascetic life. It would endanger their eternal soul.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Which got me thinking that, uh... if these Siddhi hold so fast to their orthodoxy then what would cause them to break their faith?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: I don't know.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Something human?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Revenge?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Well, maybe, um.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is... an American chemical plant in a village in India called, uh, Vishi. It's just outside of Mumbai which is a better known to us as Bombay. About six months ago the plant inadvertently released a small cloud of methyl isocyanate gas. 118 of Vishi's mostly indigenous population were killed. But it wasn't very well reported over here. I spent all night cross-checking the, uh, victims of the disaster. And one... finally caught my attention.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Now, I'd say, right here. It's an 11-year-old boy... whose father is described as being a holy man of the Chamar caste.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: The beggar caste. Fakirs and mystics are.... well, often of low birth.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you think that this boy's father could be a Siddhi mystic like you described?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: He could be. But if he's out for revenge then why is he killing the people that he's killing?

speaker: TREVOR'S MOTHER
line: Woo! What's the matter with you?

speaker: TREVOR
line: Nothing.

speaker: TREVOR'S MOTHER
line: Trevor? Where are you going? Dinner's on the table.

speaker: TREVOR'S MOTHER
line: Trevor. Trevor? Dinner.

speaker: TREVOR'S MOTHER
line: Trevor!

speaker: TREVOR'S FATHER
line: Excuse me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: She came out to call her son in for dinner. That's all we know.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: What are we doing here, Agent Scully 'cause I'm not sure.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are we doing? A woman died of mysterious circumstances not three blocks away from a previous victim. External signs are a direct match. That woman's eyes.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: I saw her eyes. But dollars to donuts there wasn't anything that crawled up inside her. Now, I think we're reaching here and I don't know how to say it but maybe you're seeing things that you want to see.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are you questioning my integrity?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: No, I'm questioning the whole damn case. From your so-called expert, to the evidence you've chosen to ignore, to the fact that your approach has got us no closer to seeing a pattern or a motive or even catching this killer than we were when we started.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I asked you to keep an open mind.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Yeah, well, I try to keep an open mind but it tends to shut my eyes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: There is something here, Agent Doggett. And I'll admit that it's hard to accept. But there is a motive and there is a pattern and there is a reason and we will see it... but not working like this.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Yeah, well... I hope somebody sees it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Trevor. Trevor, I'm Dana Scully...

speaker: TREVOR
line: What happened?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Your father's in the house. I'm going to take...

speaker: TREVOR
line: Where's my mom?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Trevor.

speaker: TREVOR
line: He was here. The-the little man. I-I saw him. He... he followed me.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Agent Doggett? Where is he? Is that him?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: If you mean the janitor yeah, that's him, right in there.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Agent Scully called and said that, uh, you had arrested what might be an honest to goodness Siddhi mystic.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Well, Agent Scully jumped the gun on that one. The only thing extraordinary about this man is he doesn't speak... to anyone.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Well, where is Agent Scully?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: She left, after four hours of attempting to interrogate this guy. Unless he jumps up and does something mystical in the next ten minutes, we're releasing him.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: What are you doing?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: The man sitting there may not be the man sitting there. No one may be there at all, in fact.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Not in the next ten minutes, there ain't.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Oh, wow. Agent Doggett? Y-you got to take a look at this.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Come on. It's a trick.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Yeah, but not of the camera.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Wait, if... if he's not there...

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: He could be anywhere.

speaker: TREVOR'S FATHER
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sir, I am so sorry to bother you again. I know this has been a terrible ordeal.

speaker: TREVOR'S FATHER
line: Yes... what is it you need?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I need to speak with your son, Trevor, again.

speaker: TREVOR'S FATHER
line: Is this about his mother?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, Trevor told me that he saw a man... It was just something that doesn't quite add up and I need to be certain.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thank you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Scully.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Think you ought to get back here, Agent Scully. There's something...

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: The janitor, he's here... but he's not. I can't... I can't explain it.

speaker: TREVOR'S FATHER
line: Trevor's not in his room.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm sorry, just hang on one second.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Agent Doggett what do you mean he's not there?

speaker: TEACHER
line: Who's that?

speaker: MRS. HOLT
line: Hello?

speaker: MRS. HOLT
line: Mr. Burrard... I thought you... Well, I-I didn't expect to see you back at work.

speaker: MRS. HOLT
line: This is the agent who picked him up before. Can you make this call?

speaker: QUINTON
line: Here he comes.

speaker: QUINTON
line: Trevor, are you there?

speaker: TREVOR
line: Get out of there, let's go!

speaker: QUINTON
line: I can't, the windows are locked.

speaker: TREVOR
line: Break them, okay!? You...

speaker: TREVOR
line: I'll get help.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, thank god.

speaker: QUINTON
line: Do something!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Quinton, what's the matter?

speaker: QUINTON
line: It's him! It's the little man!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who? Trevor?

speaker: MRS. HOLT
line: All right, now you boys, you just stop playing around.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Okay, don't move. Stay where you are.

speaker: MRS. HOLT
line: Wait, wait what are you doing?

speaker: QUINTON
line: Stop him! Shoot him!

speaker: SCULLY
line: I can't.

speaker: MRS. HOLT
line: Oh, my god.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: What is it, what happened? Agent Scully! Scully.

speaker: [CARRIK
line: First time he's called her Scully?]

speaker: DOGGETT
line: You going to be okay, Agent Scully?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: I got a drift of what happened in there... to you. I mean, sort of.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I shot a young boy.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: The good news is, you're wrong.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But it's what I saw. With my eyes, anyway. Do you know what it's like not to be able to trust your own eyes?

speaker: DOGGETT
line: Then why'd you shoot him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Because it's what the boy saw. And in an instant I realized that it's what Mulder would have seen or understood.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Because that's just how he came at things... without judgment and without prejudice and with an open mind that I am just not capable of.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: It's been a long night. Give yourself a break.

speaker: DOGGETT
line: This whole thing doesn't make any sense.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No... it did. In some way, it did.
